remixed_from.author: george6robles
remixed_from.title: GT MK8 Auto level for Prusa i3 Pro B

title: MK8 Auto level for Geeetech Pro B Pro C or 40mm Fan mount Mach 2

description.text:
MACH 2 for my MK8 auto level bracket. same instructions as before but watch the video on you tube for updates on what I do and how to set up the magnets for a pro c and a pro b like setup for an MK8 extruder setup or like 40mm fan mount for the pro c By Geeetech. I have been trying to figure out a way to auto deploy it with a bracket that mounts to my on pro b X axis motor mount. this design is a little better and retracts the probe a little sooner then before. I am currently testing this design but I was pretty happy with the design so I decided to share it now. this is a stronger version of the design that will work better for pro b and pro c like setup. the deploy bracket needs much more work to work correctly.
I have posted more on my wordpress page for my settings and the g-code I use to retract the z probe.
so for now its a manual deploy, retractable z probe via some g-code.
I have posted my g-code for the deploy movements and the retraction movements, as well as sharing my slic3r config's.

I am the Beginning of the USA based Geeetech sales and customer support. Help support me and my venture, please check out my store that I'm currently setting up, georges3dprinters.com
I have been providing tech support for Geeetech customers for a few months now and have had great reviews. help me help others.
video on YouTube:
https://youtu.be/IcuFkOzr-5k
https://youtu.be/WtjIAIQPWlc

I used two 6mm by 10mm N50/N52 cylinder magnets for the mount and one for the screw on the arm. for pro b. as for the pro c you need a different setup on the magnets using a smaller 3mm by 4mm N52 magnet in a different arrangement. check out my YouTube channel for more info

comments.text:
this wouldn't slice right with cura so here is a fixed one if its giving you trouble
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:955228
comments.author: amigone

comments.text: How would this work on an i3c and plug into the gt2560 board?
comments.author: x306xcptnkirk

comments.text:
Just uses existing z min stop. Can set it to any you want via pins.h file in the firmware as well as other areas of the autolevel.
The GT2560 has three open pins in the max end stops. If say, you where running the full graphics LCD12864 instead of the LCD 2004, you will get three more open pins to mod, so six in all. Look up info on reprap, I seen it under Sanguinololu board info. But have to add it later in the next comment , I have to find that info again.
comments.author: x306xcptnkirk

comments.text: You would need to modify your pins.h, and use your max endstops plugs. Since your not using those that's a good place. Another hint. If you have the FIRST gt2560 board where you need a splitter cable you only have 2 pins per socket for the max and min endstops. However if you have Rev A, you have 2 pins per socket too, but if you flip the board over you will see there is a 3rd hole. It is hooked up too, just need to enable it and do what I did. Get XH2.5 sockets and desolder the 2 pins, install 3 pin and now you have more pins!
comments.author: x306xcptnkirk

remixed_from.title: Raspberry Pi Camera to Microscope Adapter

title: Canon EF Lens adapter for Raspberry Pi

description.text:
Make your pi camera super-telescope with Canon EF lens.......
For people did not have accessible 3D printer, another model in shapesway (http://shpws.me/Hz4u) should do the same trick.

update for The new 8MP V2.1 camera.
The picam_ef_adapter_v2.1.stl should work on both old (5MP) and new (8MP) camera modules.

comments.text: Nice fit on the lens side!!
comments.author: BjornTh

comments.text:
I was not able to 3D print your design.
looks like there are issues with non-manifold and naked edges...at least according to Rhino CAD.
Can you look into this?

comments.text:
The focal length of stock lens should be 3.6mm. (From https://www.raspberrypi.org/forums/viewtopic.php?t=46063&p=364426)
The picture I take with stock lens was take at full resolution (2592x1944) then scale down to 1920 width and corp to 1280 height.

rubber band swimming minion

1. print: 1 x front, 1 x back, 1 x feet, 6 x pins.
    2.find a proper sized rubber band or cut and tie a knot.
  2. put the rubber band through the hole in the arm.
  3. place the arm into the front and slide the rubber band into the groove.
  4. push 4 x pin into the front.
  5. press the front and back together.
  6. push 2 x pin in the buttom.
  7. press the feet on.

A simple cup holder designed to be fastened to the handle bars of a bicycle using zip-ties.
This is my first design that is not ready to use directly after printing it, some assembly is required. I used super glue to hold the three parts together.
I printed this in a little lower resolution, 0.205 mm/layer in order to speed things up. With 15% infill, the print took just below 2 hours to finish.

title: Adjustable Monitor Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Free up a tiny bit of desk space and improve your posture with this adjustable PC monitor stand.
While looking at a monitor precariously placed on top of a cardboard box I realised there was another use I could make of the light mounting on my rotary hydroponic design. So I beefed up the supporting beam a bit to help it support the extra weight of a monitor and added captive nut slots for easy adjustment, then created the rest of the frame, and voila, a very simple monitor stand.
I'm currently looking at a monitor on its built-in stand that ruins my posture when working, so I hope to make one of these.

All the bolts used in this design are M4x30mm. The right-angle short bars are 200mm M8 studding, the bars standing up are 500mm, and the 45-degree support bars are 100mm, but of course make them whatever length you need. The distance between the two upright bars can be 150mm with room for a little adjustment. The bars across between the two base parts are not strictly necessary, but they add rigidity to the structure. Also you could use them for a handy little shelf if you include them.
The parts are designed for simplicity, but I hope that anyone who cares can optimise them a bit. For extra awesome, print the parts in the same colour ABS as your monitor's case. :)

comments.text:
What size monitor have you tested it?
How would you say is doing? (is stable? or are you afraid and careful? :P
comments.author: atanasovgoran

comments.text: Well, there's another way of doing it that should allow you to tilt the monitor, and print the parts on a TOM - added a pair of swivel brackets.
comments.author: 4ndy

comments.text: This is brilliant.
comments.author: fmotta

comments.text: Hmm, good point, it's a bit too long to go on one of those diagonally.
comments.author: fmotta

comments.text: Good work! However, there is no way to adjust the tilt. Would it work to just put a spacer between the mounts and the monitor?
comments.author: Jamo

comments.text: Indeed, it's only height adjustable right now, I'll take suggestions for a way to tilt it so that it will stay in the position you put it in without wearing out, or you can make a derivative if you have a good idea you want to put down.
comments.author: Jamo

This Heater Block is an advanced version of previously published heater block to be used on Makergear hot ends or DIY designs. Advancements are:
  • Use of M3 stud screw-on thermistor. It is easy to install and remove, makes assembly and maintanance of hot end really simple.
  • Another useful feature is ability of heater block assembly to be secured on barrel with M3 x 6 set screw. This will prevent block from twist during nozzle changes. This feature is similar to one found in updated budaschnozzle 1.2 heater block design, it was implemented in response to requests from users of previous version. Thank you for your feedback!
    • Drawings and instructions are provided, or you can get completed, manufactured parts here:
    http://www.ebay.com/itm/221228407572
    http://www.ebay.com/itm/321108299432

I supplied detailed PDF drawings of this design, along with STL and STEP solid model. There is enough information to manufacture and assemble these heater blocks. Guidelines for aluminum blocks are basically the same as for previous version: I.) For CNC machining: This thing to be machined from 3/8" x 3/4" 6061-T6 extruded bar, then tapped M3 & M6 according to drawing. Machining strategy is up to you. Use STL / STEP files and drawing to create G-code. II.) You can make it manually from 3/8" x 3/4" 6061-T6 extruded bar stock:
  • Cut 18.5mm long piece of extruded bar preferably with band saw.
    Manual hack saw gives less straight cut, you might need to file
    rough side for better appearance.
  • Mark hole centers according to drawing.
  • Drill necessary holes using drill press (not manual drill),
    consult with drawing for drill bit diameters. Make small pilot holes
    prior to drill holes for M6 and heater, for better centering.
  • Tap M6 hole preferably on the drill press, for straigtness.
  • M3 holes can be tapped manually.
    • Making of M3 stud thermistor is straigth forward. See drawing for details. You will need:
  • NTC EPCOS thermistor.
  • M3 x 4 brass standoff.
  • 0.3mm ID PTFE tubing.
  • JST crimp-on connector male & female. Similar to one used for small rc aircraft batteries.
  • JB Weld steel epoxy resin.
    • Sequence of operations:
  • Put 55-57mm long pieces of PTFE tubing on thermistor leads.
  • Crimp female contacts on thermistor leads.
  • Prepare epoxy mix and put small portion of epoxy inside M3 hex standoff.
  • Secure brass standoff and insert thermistor with PTFE tubing and conector.
  • Keep thermistor leads straigth until epoxy cured. You might need to develop some kind of fixture to hold parts together.
    • Hex thermistor safely rated up to 500F / 260C for prolonged period of time because it uses JB Weld steel epoxy to fix thermistor in hex stud housing.

comments.text: Where can you source the parts for the thermistor?  I haven't been able to find the .3 PTFE tubing, I found .32 PTFE Tubing or the fasteners.
comments.author: bbriggstkd

comments.text: .32mm ID PTFE will be perfectly fine, I think. You can make a google or ebay search for 0.3mm ID tubing and find a lot of sources. M3 Brass hex stud is commonly used item for PC motherboard mounting. There are also #6-32 studs available, they are tiny bit larger, aside of different thread size, but this is Ok for DIY. Same here: search and find a lot of sources. I did not supply part numbers because it makes not much sense to buy M3 brass studs from mcmaster, they were too expensive last time I checked.
comments.author: bbriggstkd

comments.text: Neat design.  I'm curious, however - I'm assuming you are using "JB Weld", which is rated at 200c+ only for short periods.  I had a problem with it turning onto a nice grey power over time....
comments.author: SystemsGuy

comments.text: Thank you. GB Weld, according their own packaging, rated up to 550F / 287C when fully cured. I de-rated this number a little, to be completely safe. It was already used under 240 C for long time, no problems at all. According to other source, temperature of 600F / 316C is possible for 10 minutes. This stuff is used to fix engine blocks.
comments.author: SystemsGuy

description.text:
This is my first Tinkercad experiment. Was meant to just be a plate but I've added a hole (M3) to mount to the frame. I will be remaking it with 2 mount points and a loop to thread my filament thru to give it some function. I do not expect this to be of use for anyone but perhaps it will inspire an idea. Feel free to modify for own use.

As a side note, I nicknamed my printer Slave in the firmware (wanted to name it after something futuristic, Boba Fett [Star Wars] pilots the Slave ship.. also its been slaving away since I built it so kind of a joke there).

Portafoto per neonato. Personalizzalo con nome e data.
Gift for new born.
This thing was made with Tinkercad.
Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/b2OuVNMv3yE

I designed this insert to repair one of my Aura-pro base shakers as it had cracked making it useless for its purpose.

I forgot to take picture of the repaired kicker and it's now back in place and not so easy to remove from my driving sim.
For those that have them this is a very useful file and can also be printed in other materials and thickness to further tune your shaker.
I printed it in ABS Black with 100% infill and glued it back into place after carefully picking away at the rivet I managed to reuse it and restored my broken kicker to a fully working one.

title: Direct Drive Bowden extruder for Mk8 drive V5
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This part is designed specifically for an Mk8 drive gear with an effective drive OD of 7mm. It attaches directly to the motor and has no provision for attachment to the machine since that may be different for almost everyone. I'm using mine on a Kossel 2020, and therefore I used my Kossel 2020 extruder stepper mount. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:783695

I've tested this extruder and drive gear for over a year now and have done prints as long as 16 hours with it.

This design incorporates a solid body to facilitate completely enclosed teflon guide tubing. Maximum filament support was desired to work better with flexible filaments. This is intentionally not an open, minimal design like you see almost everywhere else.

See instructions for a list of required parts and assembly information.

Modeled in DesignSpark Mechanical.

UPDATE1: Fillet radius on tensioner arm mounting ears was increased to address concerns about strength.

UPDATE2
The arm has been beefed up and the idler bearing axis has been moved slightly closer to the drive wheel. This provides extra headroom for the tensioner arm so that it won't bottom out. The Ver 4a part seemed to be sagging over time and almost bottoming. This shouldn't be a problem now. Version 4a has been deleted and replaced with Version 5.

A separate version with a nutcatch pocket for an M3 nut has been added. The slot was made 6mm wide - in order allow a 5.5mm hex nut to be easily inserted. The hole will need to be reamed oversize for clearance of the M3 screw itself.

Version 5 is the last version uploaded to Thingiverse. The extruder has been significantly improved upon since then, but I have been advised NOT to upload it to thingiverse because the Makerbot/Stratasys empire and their herd of vulture lawyers do not respect intellectual property rights. They effectively claim ownership of anything uploaded here and they reserve the right to use, sell, or even patent it as their own, They have stolen extruder designs in the past when they saw something they could profit from.

You will need an M3 x 20 screw for the spring tensioner. The spring I used is a commonly available small engine part - mine was a mixture adjustment screw spring from an old RC airplane gas engine. I think that a spring from the carburetor mixture screw of most any weed whacker, chainsaw, etc, should also be the right size. Common build platform springs from eBay will also work work, but aren't quite as stiff.
The hole that the spring tensioner screw goes through will almost certainly need to be reamed out a little. You want to be able to move the arm - with the screw installed - for at least 3 to 4 mm without it dragging on the screw.

The screw hole on the extruder body must be tapped with an M3 tap. (unless your are using the nut-catch version)

The M6 thread for the pneumatic fitting for the teflon Bowden tube is modeled into the part. I've printed quite a few of these and the coupler always seems to thread into the part after working in gently in and out a few times. NOTE: This extruder uses the proper M6 thread PC4-M6 Pneumatic Connector intended for extruders. The larger PC4-M10 Pneumatic fitting is intended for hotends and will not fit this extruder.

The pivot point for the tensioner arm, and the axle for the ball bearing idler is 3mm diameter drill rod which has been trimmed to length. The ball bearing itself is a common 623ZZ bearing which is a part used in many other 3D printer applications.

The filament guide hole which goes the whole way up through the part is 3mm. It may need to be reamed to accept the two pieces of internal Teflon tubing. I used Teflon tubing from RobotDigg which has an O.D. of 3mm, and an I.D. of 2mm. I flared the bottom of the tubing where the filament enters - this prevents the teflon from being pushed upwards into the drive gear.
I can not say how well the extruder might work without the Teflon tubing, since that is the only way I've used it. All I can say is, if you want it to work well, build it as I intended. Please look at the pictures.

Watch the spacing on the Mk8 drive gear when you tighten down the grub screw. It must line up with the center-line of the filament guide-tube. I printed mine in PLA and cut out a thin cork gasket with my laser cutter to insulate the PLA from the heat of the extruder stepper motor. If printing in ABS, that would probably not be necessary.

Final thought: In some cases your made want to mirror the extruder body in your slicer before you print it. It depends on which direction your filament feeds in from. I recommend having it setup so that the outside of the filament (as it comes off the spool) is NOT running on the Mk8 drive wheel. Keeping the drive wheel marks on the inside of the natural curve of the filament (as it comes off the spool) helps reduce friction as it passes through the Bowden tube. This is especially important when you are printing near the end of a spool of filament. If your spool holder feeds your filament in at a 90 degree angle to the drive wheel, that seems to work great also.

comments.author: O_Lampe

comments.text:
I went through quite a few iterations to tweak the thickness and size for the external pivot ears and the bearing holder. The ears have actually been beefed-up from an earlier version. The only time I had an issue with the earlier version was when I was drilling them out to 3mm to accept the pin - and that was with PLA, which is more brittle and harder to drill.
If people report problems with the ears breaking, I can easily beef them up even more.. I've got 20+ hours on the current version. The tensioner spring has been tightened and loosened over a dozen times.

title: Blower kit for 12V DC fan, 60x60x25 mm

description.text:
(Update)

I installed the blower on my Kossel mini. Length of the air hose was 590 mm, inside diameter was 14 mm. It worked out but one issue is big noise it generates.

Outdoor application is probably okay but using it as cooling device for Hotend is questionable IMHO. Running 12V DC fan at 5V is an easy option I'll try.

I made it to use 12V DC fan as blower for Bulbul Junior 3D Printer to cool hotend or to blow air on melted filament at the nozzle.

The impeller is scaled down version of
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:209797.

Use blower2.scad to generate enclosure parts. It eliminates six spacers and the wind block.

The air hose holder is rotating 360 degrees. Diameter of exhaust port is 20.00 mm which uses 20.00 mm push fitting.

comments.text:
Clever use of the inneficient fan to make something more powerful.
The blades of the old fan will cause drag. maybe cut them off and glue the impeller to the hub of the old fan?
comments.author: gordonendersby

comments.text: That's possible option but the design goal is to use 12V DC fan as is.
comments.author: gordonendersby

title: Tick Twister
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Tick twister has been updated to Tick Twister V2, with a slightly smaller, user friendly design

As we’re in for an inundation of ticks this summer, we here at CEL have designed this handy tick twister. So if you find a Tick on yourself, a family member or a beloved pet, you no longer have to put up with a tacky supermarket tick remover or wait days for amazon shipping. Just print this handy Tick twister and get it out asap!

Recommended settings;
Resolution: Normal or Fine
Infill: 20% – 40%
Material: ABS

It is very important that the first layer is printed at 0.1mm (100micon) or less.

Removing a Tick can be a tricky business, there are a few rules that need to be followed to prevent infection as advised by BADA UK;

The tick’s body must not be compressed, as this can force out saliva and gut contents which may contain disease-causing organisms.
The tick should not be irritated or injured, as this may result in it regurgitating (vomiting) saliva and gut contents along with any disease-causing organisms.
The mouth parts of the tick should be cleanly removed along with the rest of its body.
The tick should be removed without causing the host discomfort.
When removing the Tick, wear rubber or plastic gloves.

How to use the Tick twister;

Engage the tool by approaching the tick from the side (the body of the tick is flat when unfed) until it is held securely.
Lift the tool very lightly and TURN IT (clockwise or counter-clockwise). The tick detaches itself after 2-3 rotations.
After removing the tick, disinfect the bite site and wash hands with soap and water.
You may want to save the tick for identification in case the person or animal the tick was attached to becomes ill within several weeks. To save the tick, write the date of the bite in pencil on a piece of paper and put it with the tick in a sealed plastic bag and store it in a freezer. Your doctor / vet can then identify that a tick bite has occurred and use this information to assist in making an accurate diagnosis.

comments.text: Thanks so much for this !!!
comments.author: jmaxime89

comments.text: I bought a very similar one in store. This is by far the best tick remover that you can get, period. I have to remove dozens of ticks from my dog every year and this tool hasn't failed me once. It's easy, works like magic and removes the tick completely.
comments.author: HobbyHoarder

comments.text: anyone try this? did it remove the entire tick or did it leave anything left in the skin?? very curious
comments.author: mikebaier

comments.text: my dog got a tick on his eye lid! This was gentle and very simple to remove for him.  Tick came out whole, works on ticks small and large (full).  our pups rarely get them with their meds, but we pull them off us quite often using this :P
comments.author: mikebaier

comments.text: Yes, I had to use it on my Son's friend last summer, it worked just as well as the ones you buy from the shop.
comments.author: mikebaier

comments.text: This piece looks great! I do have one major issue with it, however.
comments.author: awdemuth

comments.text: That's because most people try to twist with a tool designed to clamp around the tick, like tweezers or their fingernails. This causes the mouthparts to break and increases the chance of contracting diseases through the tick's bodily fluids.
comments.author: awdemuth

comments.text: Fantastic! I just found a tick on my dog and all the stores and vets are closed! I thought id take a chance and lord and behold! you saved the day. Prints like a charm and works even better. Thank you soo much! btw I printed mine with proto pasta carbon pla with 0.2 layer height.

comments.text: Yeah this is what i was looking for. Thank you :-) Will post when i printed this thingy

author: CEL-UK

title: Glass plate heat bed mounts with cage nuts

description.text:
As my new borosilicate glass plate was delivered I was looking for a quick solution for mounting it to the heat bed.

I found out that "cage nuts" normally used in server racks for holding hardware are working too very good. This cage nuts are nearly everywhere available - amazon, ebay or in local computer stores.

The mounts are easy to remove for cleaning the glass plate & take parts off plus the bed stay leveled when remount it.

It holds my glass plate very well since weeks so I wanted to share it.
Remove the nut, simple bent sides & mount them on glass plate (look at the pics).

A derivative of the above thing, further parametrized - i.e.
  • you can flip the head, the legs, and both arms
  • you can set a custom tolerance to allow the prints to interlock properly
    • Feel free to flattr this or the original design, if you support our interconnected robot overlords.

Edit the scad file to your needs, export to STL, print.
You may particularly want to reduce the arm length if you decide to print a both-arms-inside-bot. Two example STLs with a tolerance of 0.3mm are provided, one of which you can connect to infinite chains (or plains, even!)

Sans-serif vector font designed using OpenSCAD primitives

This alphabet is constructed using simple shapes, and includes source code for each letter.

Capital letters only (for now). All standard English letters are now done.

A simple letter writing module is also included, which uses an array of letter widths with customisable gaps to put letters into the model.

This is a custom font created specifically for 3D printing; feel free to take and modify it as you like.

comments.text:
That looks tedious to code but super fast to render.
Looking at stl coding, it would seem relatively simple to code a script to generate openscad polygon data from STL file triangle data. So you could write a target font in the CAD of your choice with letters stacked at precise distance increments and read the triangle vertexes, subtract the letter distances and convert the individual characters to polygon.
Or are you doing something like this ? :-)
comments.author: fluidity

comments.text: There are plenty of other STL-based fonts on thingiverse. This one is different from most of them in that it's precisely coded with OpenSCAD primitives, so curves can be modelled to the desired accuracy, and possibly modified as people see fit. It's mostly just me fiddling around with OpenSCAD to see if it could be done, and it's proving to be not too much more difficult than creating a font from my own handwriting.

title: Mostly Printed CNC - Tool holder for Mastergrip Rotary Tool

description.text:
Update 7/19/2015
Rev8 fixes a clearance problem I did not see until putting this together. This version should work now.

I already have one of these Mastergrip tools I bought from Costco years ago which I believe is the same one listed below in this amazon link. This tool weighs 18.6oz. After installing this on the Z-axis pipes, it slides nicely between the bolts.
http://www.amazon.com/Mastergrip-190pc-Rotary-Tool-Accessory/dp/B005HKMASS

This upper & lower tool holder I made fits nicely around this tool with a snug fit after putting the bolt & nut on. There is a 53mm distance between the nuts on the nut trap. You could vary that distance anywhere between 25mm & 70mm, but 53mm puts it in a spot where the heat vents for the tool are not located. I have not actually put this together on the Z tower yet, but seems like it should fit unless I missed something in the design. The bottom part is 49mm ID. The top part has a different inside profile to get around parts protruding on the rotary tool.

Parts to print for this are:
1 - tool_Holder_49mmLower_rev8_repaired.stl
1 - tool_Holder_52mmUpper_rev8_repaired.stl
2 - Tool_Holder_53mmNut_Trap.stl
(The MasterGripRotaryTool.stl is a rough model of rotary tool for reference only)

Print times for these on my printer were 2:10:45 for Lower part & 01:38:40 for the Upper part.

You can also edit the included openscad files instead. If the Nut trap is the wrong size for you, you can use http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:907882 to make the size you want. Feel free to point out any problems I may not have seen in this design.

I measured the noload wattage on this rotary tool at 23watts (low speed) to 60 watts (hi speed).

comments.text:
Dave,
I'd like to use the lower part at least to mount a Metabo #738 router. It has a base cylinder of 43mm diameter. Modifying the scad file to match that was no problem. What do I have to do, though, to adapt the design to the IE 25mm tube standard?
comments.author: Chattermark

comments.text: I just measured this one in Cadd & the IE 13mm 25mm tube & they are fairly close.  This one measures 61.31mm between 23.5 pipes & the IE version of 25mm tube measures 60.55mm.  That is less than 1mm difference, but you also have the difference of 1.5mm in diameter.  Hope that helps.  I could probably make an IE version of this fairly easy, if that would be helpful.  It might be a trial & error for you though.
comments.author: Chattermark

comments.text:
Thanks for the prompt reply again!
If it's not too much of work for you, the rapidly growing followership of the MPCNC project would probably be more than happy to find another fine template for the IE version.
Looking forward... - Thanks in advance!
comments.author: GeoDave

title: Projector (Acer) Remote Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A simple holder for a remote, e.g. for your projector! Designed to hold a 140x45x20 mm Acer remote but should work for many more with little or no scaling.
Also makes for a good overhang test - this design prints without supports as it features only 45° overhangs and five short gaps to bridge.

Printed in PLA with 0.3 mm layers and 30 % infill - no support, but good cooling needed.

I attached it to a beam on my IKEA shelf using hot_soup_in_space's Bongo Tie Rubber Band Cable Fasteners. A nice side effect of using rubber bands rather than zip ties is the greatly increased friction between plastic and wood which keeps your holder where you wanted it to be :-)

author: LokusArts

remixed_from.author: QuadFramesUK
remixed_from.title: DJI Inspired (3D Printable Quad / Multirotor) Upgrades

description.text:
Want a DJI Inspire One but don't want to spend $3K? Then this is the 3D printing project for you! The cost of building the frame and landing gear is only around $100. Add your electronics and get in the air for far less than DJI would charge.

This is my project that evolved from the idea RCHobbiesUK developed. The RCGroups community took off from their inspiration and mutated their design into an entirely new beast that has considerable improvements.

The full list of options, print settings, print checklist, hardware, electronics, wiring, and everything else can be read in full at the RCGroups thread http://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2399740#post31442294

The complete set of modeling files is on that page as well! So if you want to put your own twist on my design you won;t need to start from scratch.

comments.text: Would it be possibile to attach an hd camera? How much did you spend in total to make this drone? And also: did you include some sort of flight assistant or sensors that can help you during high altitude flights?
comments.author: Donchuck

comments.text:
Yes. There is a camera attachment point under the nose.
However, keep in mind that the max carry weight is less than one kilogram and depends on your electronics/propeller setup.

title: Sturdy Kossel Z-Probe Retractor
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Z probe retractor supplied by the retailer did not work well at all and broke after I bumped into it while working on the bed clips (see second photo), so I quickly drew up a replacement in TinkerCAD and so far it works like a charm :-)

  • larger and sturdier than the original
  • attached by two screws instead of one
  • dimple to prevent sideways movement of the probe

Printed in PLA with 0.3 mm layers and 50 % infill.

The part attaches to a 2020 extrusion (or any other) with two 8 mm M3 screws and two T-slot nuts.

Make sure to adjust your configuration before running a bed levelling command, the retractor point WILL be off by a little bit!

title: X-Box (pronounced Cross-Box)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Originally devised for board games where both players might like their own box while playing, this turned out to be quite decorative in my opinion!
The box features four separate compartments, two of which belong to each half. There is also a lid of course, held in place by an M20 screw and an integrated nut in the bottom half.

Looks best if printed in several colors - I'm curious to see what you'll make of it!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Huxley

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

30 %

Notes:

no support needed if you have decent cooling!

(designed entirely in Tinkercad)
I started out with the model for the M20 screw and nut by Nenoti and modeled the bottom part of the box based on the width of the nut and a length I thought would look nice in relation.
Next I folded a paper box with that footprint and measured how high the game pieces I was making the box for would fill it, that gave me my floor-to-ceiling height.
The second container was easy in comparison, just kind of flipped upside down and with a simple hole in the middle rather than a threaded nut.
Shortening the screw in Tinkercad was quite a bit of work and convinced me to start learning new software rather sooner than later, but turned out fine in the end!

comments.text: This looks like an amazing compliment for your Twixt set. How many pegs fit in one of the four compartments? How many links?
comments.author: peyrol

comments.text:
26-27 pegs fit in one compartment, and 14 more in the opposite one on top of all 50 links of that color. So far I've never come short of pegs playing TwixT, but one might need more than that for playing Reversi, for instance...my printer limited me to 14 cm across :-P
To remember which side the links are in, I added a narrow strip of electrical tape resembling a link on that side.

author: Jehnune

description.text:
After much pain trying to level with springs and to to hold the tolerance the TOM can print. I designed in ST3 a platform leveler that can level at easy to .001 of an inch and less. This design allows you to get to all four corners and easly and to ajust them to the right height and lock them into place. I uploaded STP files of all the parts for those who have requested a file they can change or manipulate. STP and IGES files are pretty much universial in the 3D world so most should be able to read them in. I designed the parts in Solid Edge ST3 so the virgin files are done in this. If someone needs a different format send me a note and I will do my best to help. Update: Please use JinxTheRabbit's version of the HBP Leveler Part1 A.stl part it prints much better than mine! Please down load his version at
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13023 he added a raft to the support and it works great! Note: I added IGES file of complete HBP assembly so folks can have access to all the parts and change them to there liking.

1st Print 4 of the platform brackets and 8 of the thumb wheels. 2nd Insert the 4 3mm nuts into the four corners for locking the platform to your TOM. Do this on all 4 corners. 3rd Bolt 4 brackets togehter using 8 3mm flat head socket screws and 8 3mm nuts. I used ones that are from McMaster Car # 949004-100. 4th Use 4 thum screws 3mm by 12mm long thumb screws to mount the platform to your TOM X wood plate. I used ones from Mcmaster car, you could also just use 4 3mm x 12mm hex bolts. I used thumbs so i could get it off easy for furture need. 5th Load eight 3mm nuts into the printed thumbs parts. I glued mine in so they where very tight and would not come lose. 6th Screw on 4 to each post, them load the HBP plate on the the platform with thumb scerws inserted and scew the plate down to your leveling height. Note the holes on the wood X plate need to be inlarged so the scews slip into them very easly!! Note: Part1_A has support added for over hangs and Part1_B has the support removed. Leveling Tips: 1st: level with your TOM nice and hot!
2nd: use .001 feller gaude to set level hight to proper level.
3rd: Use control panle to set you height and them adjust leveler to set the height with the feller gauge.
Note: The feller gauge is .001" or .025mm so make sure you note this in your SF txt file calculation.

author: ventouya

description.text:
Ready to print garden signs. Label your garden and know whats what. More signs will be added soon, or upon request!

Website Page:

http://jimmyloopa3d.weebly.com/garden-signs

Print Settings

Layer Hight: .3mm
Infill: 10%
Supports: no
Raft: No
Speed: Fast

This boat is simple to be printed, it is within the Replicator printing area, and needs no support.

   Boat design makes reference to the old boats used by pirates to take your treasure (usually in gold coins!) Of the island to the ships.

  It has a system in its hull able to retain air for greater buoyancy, constructed so that it is not necessary to use support.

   Made for the challenge "Make it Float" and may suffer future change without notice.

Design made in Solid Works.

I recommend printing on ABS.

It is not necessary to use support.

A mini paddle boat with a mini couple for a romantic trip on water.

See more in 'Instructions'

Firstly I designed only a mini paddle boat. Then I decided to add with hot glue two small characters (one thick man and one thick woman) to allow them a romantic trip on water.

In order to create a mini boat able to float I added two 'lateral wings' to the main body of the boat, because they increase the surface contact area with water and guarantee more stability. I tested the boat in water and, for my happiness, it works! I printed them with a Prusai3 Hephestos, with the brim feature.

Note: In order to obtain a boat small in size like that in the photos, you have to scale the .stl files. I used Cura for this purpose.

Did away with the fougasse​ clips

4 shells
50% infill
ABS

I use Simplfy3d (s3d) for slicing and had -0.20mm horizontal size compensation ticked and the stock mbi tubes fit perfect!

For flashForge, you will need to resize it 1mm in the x or y axis as they are 34mm wide compared to mbi's 33mm

Enjoy!

A model of the hull of an Americas Cup boat. The forward ends of the pontoons are the ones that have the taper and the angle. The fore cross piece is the one that has a thinner width. All the pieces are arranged in one file to reduce print time.

1. Download and print file
  2. Put the cross pieces in the slots of one pontoon and glue w/ poly cement or other. (Thinner one in front)
  3. Glue the cross pieces in the other pontoon.

title: Triangular Softball Display
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Whether you play yourself or not, it's always good to keep those souvenir balls from rolling off the shelf!

If you'd like custom text on the side, drop me a message or just edit it yourself - I used TinkerCAD and InkScape (the font is "Buffalo Nickel").

Also check out the baseball version :-)

The plain one works fine at 0.3 mm layer height, but I'd recommend a higher resolution if you print one with writing on the side. I printed mine in PLA with 20 % infill, but you could go even lower if you want.

author: LokusArts

title: Americas Cup Catamaran Hull With Quarter Slots #MakeItFloat

description.text: The same model as my Americas Cup Catamaran Hull Model #MakeItFloat, except it has slots for quarters in the pontoons. The forward ends of the pontoons are the ones that have the taper and the angle. The fore cross piece is the one that has a thinner width. All the pieces are arranged in one file to reduce print time.

1. Download and print file
  2. Put the cross pieces in the slots of one pontoon and glue w/ poly cement or other. (Thinner one in front)
  3. Glue the cross pieces in the other pontoon.
  4. Put it in water
  5. Put quarters in the slots

[EDIT:] first version was a bit loose: the holding teeth were too small so I've added some length & updated the files.   
I got tired to remove broken pieces of filament in the plastic tubes and losing a print because of that. So I moved the spool spinners to the top using the cover holes and printed a few of these guides.   
Works like a charm now and changing colors is not an hassle anymore!

Easy to print. I've printed 4 at the same time to let the top layers cool down a bit.
The inventor file is provided if you want to adapt to a different track size.

comments.text: I was looking for a way to route wires to power some LEDs to illuminate the print bed (it's rather dark in there) and this great idea would work well for that. And good for what it's designed for, too! Thanks!
comments.author: tetralite

comments.text:
Great idea, I agree it's kind of dark some time.
Though with the spools on the top I don't have to mess with things under the platform so it's not so much an issue now.
If you think it's not strong enough (teeth too small) just tell me I'll upload an other STL.

comments.text:
I printed this. It came out very well. Some z-banding on the weapons because they're so fine, but that's a printer limitation not the model.
If I were to print it again, I would edit the files and add in holes on the mated faces so that I could put in alignment pins. That way when you glue it, there's something for the glue to hold on to and the pieces stay well aligned. Also, since the mating faces are both on the print bed, set the printer to not overprint the first layer. By default my printer overprints the first layer at 120%. This will create a seam when you join the to sections. Set this to 100% to get a seamless fit.

comments.author: Eagleknot

comments.text:
What printer? Setup (nozzle size,...)? Material (ABS, PLA, Nylon,...)? Settings?
Sounds like the issue is one or many of these: Extruder temp too high, printing speed too fast, layer height too high.
Try to decrease the extruder temp a few degrees, external (active) cooling may also help, set the printing speed at around 30mm/s and layer height not higher than 0.20mm.
If you get to print the threads without issues but still, the fit is too tight you may try (to decrease a little bit more the temp and/or) scale up the nut in the X and Y dimensions (do not scale Z !).
Hope it helps.

comments.text: if you want these to work from the supplied (defective) .stl files make sure to Scale the Nut 1.05 for X and Y and 1.02 for Z axis. The nut in the sample was larger than the .stl model by the factors I suggested.
comments.author: briankb

comments.text:
Don't take me wrong, every comment is very welcome, specially when it's meant to help people to successfully print one of my designs however... this sounds weird. Did you try to download and print the files from this page?
Scaling up the nut may still be required depending (on many things, mostly) on how fine tuned (hardware and software) is the printer. What it doesn't make much sense to me is having to apply a different amount of scaling on X and Y. Apparently that would suggest an issue in the tensioning of the corresponding belts, being the issue worse in the belts from one axis than the other. This being said, then it doesn't make sense that the bolt doesn't show this deformation.
The "supplier" from this STL has been printing thousands of those, not only to send as a sample but also to give away at numerous events. Again, it doesn't make much sense that they bother to scale them to print or that they modified the bundled STL.
I would really appreciate if you could mail me the "defective" STL files at my thingiverse name (gmail dot com) so I can check them, thanks!

comments.text:
Mine didn't fit together, but I fixed it! They weren't perfectly round, and jammed. So I dropped the nut (made of PLA) in a cup of boiling water, then ran it on the bolt. Better, but still stiff. Then I heated the bolt, and used the improved nut to ease the thread. When the bolt cooled, it fitted perfectly!
A useful way to get PLA things to fit.

author: novaspirit

title: Measure the wind, a 3D printed anemometer

description.text:
Measure the wind, a 3D printed anemometer

Finally we know what Sherlock Holmes was carrying around all the time… it was an anemometer, the picture clearly proves that. With the smoke of his pipe he determined the precise direction of the wind to make an accurate velocity measurement.

Whatever how you want to catch the wind, it might be handy to be able to measure its strength.

This contribution has three printed parts and a small DC motor. When the shaft of the motor is rotated, no resistance by internal magnets should be felt. Except for small PC fans (where magnetic resistance is clearly felt), most of the smaller DC motors are O.K.
Test the motor with the fan by blowing and checking the voltage.
It will probably read about 1.5 Volts.
The distance of the mounting holes for the motor can be chanced in the Open SCAD file at the indicated place.

Rather than implementing electronics, which would bring this gadget out of reach for most of us, it has the two motor wires connected to a universal meter.

Calibration.
Ready for calibration? Get in the car, hold the instrument outside the window and ask the driver to call out the speed. Note the speed and the voltage. Do this for a variation of velocities but make sure that you respect the speed limits. At home, the values are plotted in Excel to give you a perfect calibration curve. Don't expect a straight line, DC motors generally show an S-curve.

Tip for use: Who blows 35 km/hr at a party of your kids.
The fan blades are under an angle of 60 degrees. None of the parts need support.

description.text:
Needed a sink plug for the laundry sink to bathe my pug. Home Depot didn't carry the right size. Designed to fit 1.25" to 1.75" drain hole with a strong ring for a beaded chain.
Edit 1: Replaced STL with a 50% scale version because Repetier Host seems to import it too large despite exact dimensions in FreeCad. FreeCAD file is attached if you want to make alterations.

Print with 40-50% infill and 3-4 permimeter and do whatever you can to prevent warping with ABS (ABS/Acetone slurry). Can also be sprayed with rubber coating for a 100% watertight fit, but it works in fiberglass sinks without the coating.

Here is my original design for this eggcup:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:904510

Tried to create this same design in a different software. This time I used Autodesk 123D Design. So now it has a slimmer design.

Printed with Robox, no support needed.

title: Nema 17 mount (with plane and pads for printing)

description.text:
Derived from Nema 17 Bracket made by Jimi_Hendrik.
I was in the need to print a thing regardless of having bad adhesion caused by low heated bed temperature.
That's why I'v added a bottom plane with pads.
To be removed after the print.
Remove the plane by cutting alongside the outer perimeter of the mount body.

Update:

  • V3 has the mountbody sunken into the plane with pads
    This keeps the original dimensions (esp. hight) intact.

Have one thing printed.

  • The grip was ok.
  • No warping with the lower edges.
  • But it needs some kind of cooling with those parts.
    The upper egde gets tilted toward the bottom surface.
    Not a big deal this time;-)

A single solid shell detailed replica of a Viper with some changes to assist with the build. I haven't printed this one yet so I might have to make some edits for FDM. etc.

A cone composed of three parts. The cone base, the first color of the actual cone, and the second color of the actual cone, recommended to not flush the object to platform other than the base as it will cause issues. Do not move them separately! Can be printed with 2X for multi-colored cone or as a single color!

Place cone_base. Next add either the cone_orange or cone_otcol. If it asks for the platform to be level say no, to the cone_orange or cone_otcol. Place the other one you did not place. Say no to the platform once again. Select the cone_base and cone_orange and change the extruder to left or right (whatever desired color in your spindles), select cone_otcol and choose the opposite extruder for the other color. If you do not have a 2X, ignore the previous instructions.

comments.text: As always, a matter of opinion. You could go about just printing each an every piece separately with different colors, then glue then. What I was saying was for the 2X if you wanted to.

description.text:
Reduce your drinking glass consumption! We often had the same situation at home especially in the summer when you (should) drink a lot: There are many tumblers standing around so which one is mine? hmm - don't know - let's take a new one.
To get rid of that unnecessary consumption just print a few of these in different colors and put them onto your drinking glasses.

comments.text: Simple but really clever design - and that's why I've made it my Thing of the Week on 3D Genius:
comments.author: SteveCaplin

comments.text: Thank you very much, I'm glad to hear this. Nice article!
comments.author: SteveCaplin

comments.text: great idea, I want to do this and add a number to them and remind folks of their numbers to tell them apart when we get groups of 15-20 kids.

title: Mariel and Zoe, pregnant woman scanned with Kinect.

description.text:
Looking for a way to scan in 3D but discovered an inexpensive way they could do with a Kinect camera and a free software you download from the Internet. The model is my dear friend Mariel who carries in his bientre the little Zoe is now just a few months. The process was pretty simple, on a turntable I got a rack for old tv situé to the model as a meter away the camera. Realise scanning the top down into three sections, which subsequently edited with Zbrush achieving this result. The only thing is I was not very happy in the reostro not managed a very nice touch, but I am sure that better way to scan an excellent result would be achieved.

Buscando una forma de escanear en 3 dimensiones pero de una forma económica descubrí que lo podia hacer con una cámara Kinect y un software gratuito que descargue de internet. La modelo es mi querida amiga Mariel quien lleva en su bientre a la pequeña Zoe que hoy tiene solo algunos meses de vida. El proceso fué bastante simple, sobre una plataforma giratoria que conseguí de un rack para tv viejo situé a la modelo y a un metro de distancia la cámara. El escaneo lo realisé de arriba a abajo en tres secciónes, las cuales posteriormente edité con Zbrush logrando este resultado. En lo único que no quedé muy conforme es en el reostro que no logré un muy buen detalle, pero estoy seguro que mejorando la forma de escanear se lograria un excelente resultado.

author: rubennc91

description.text:
Submitted for the #LightItUp Challenge. Not being one who's quick with electrical circuits, I decided to make my mod from something pervasive and hopefully easy to acquire. I took a $1 solar garden lamp I purchased from a BigBox store and create a hole in a mason jar lid. Now I can place the reusable resource where ever I want. not jus in the garden. Simple but it works for me. I made wide mouth and regular size ones these are the super cheap 30mm round hole. Kinda like catching fireflies in a jar, kinda.
edit: forgot to mention I used this as the base model
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19105

comments.text: You should experiment with putting different stuff in the jars to see if you can cast better light.
comments.author: GamerGorman20

comments.text: Thanks GG20  That's a great idea. I was thinking more along the lines of glass beads. but I like the talc Idea, it would diffuse the light much better.
comments.author: GamerGorman20

comments.text: Actually, some talc spray might work better than the powder. Like gold bond athletes foot spray. You can buy small travel cans of it at pharmacies.

title: Over the Top Mendel Max 2 Spoolholder for 8mm Rod

description.text:
This is a derivative of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:77301. I really liked the design of the spool holder but it was designed for a 10mm tube and I wanted to be able to use standard skate bearings on my filament rolls. I redesigned the holder to accept a 8mm or 5/16th solid rod. I have printed it and it works perfectly! Mentioned in more detail here:
http://coherent-reprap.blogspot.com/2013/05/my-first-customized-part-new-filament.html
I just printed mine out of PLA. This is one of the first prints that I did so please excuse the poor quality print but it functions perfectly!

chess / ajedrez
This is a remake of lazzymonk's Vibration Isolator v3 adapted to the Ultimaker footprint.

Slice it with two walls - the thicknes is 4*0.4mm exactly, so it can be printed without drill-infill vibration. Make sure the walls connect firmly. It helps to over-extrude slightly. If you print the second copy mirrored, you can start testing with the back feet. It takes some force to assemble. The inner piece can be clicked down to the botton. Do this after you have forced it in place (the photo shows how to slide it in). The springs are very stiff. The Ultimaker has all its weight at the top. If the springs are too weak it can build up oscillation. Watch out for this effect at the top, not at the springs. After a few months, my back feet were notably bent. This was expected: when you put permanent load on PLA, it will creep over time. (ABS too, I'm told.) The design can handle creep to some extent. After 2.5 months, my back feet were lower but still lifting the weight (see photo above). The material I used was the PLA/PHA mix from colorfabb. I don't know if PHA makes creep better or worse. Anyway, creep deformations are permanent. You probably will have to switch front and back legs after half a year, and eventually reprint.

comments.text: I think you shouldn't be dampening the vibrations of a 3D printer. The hard jerks of the stepper motors are needed to produce sharp details in your prints. Sure, with these feet the printed model will move with the vibrations as well, but i think it's better to stick to UM's instructions of placing the printer on something solid for best results.
comments.author: 27v0XjvQTTuRUaX6xw

comments.text: well think i found a good cure for bad filament providers, found some tubing from homedepot 1/4"  just measured the extra tubing i bought (0.15$ per foot, bought enough to replace it twice) ID 4.25mm, OD 6.25mm didn't fit hot end quite right at first but i got it to work (single piece of painters tape added to the clamp to make up for the tiny difference that it had.  been testing retraction etc on it and it holds perfect, and has enough room for even the worst providers of plastic XD.  $1.00 fix for 100's(if not 1000's) of bad prints.
comments.author: 4gotten

comments.text: This made me very happy thank you.
comments.author: 4gotten

comments.text: just got my printer working(yet again...feeder snapped in 2...yeah should've seen that coming everything from that reel of plastic seems to be breaking) may i ask how well these work for your ultimaker?
comments.author: 4gotten

comments.text: I've had the latest version only for a day now. It does well so far, very solid but still flexible. No sign of sagging, but I will know in a month if PLA creep is an issue with the heavy load.
comments.author: 4gotten

comments.text: i went through the entire kg in test prints trying to get it calibrated so they'd be worth while....actually so far 2 kg from them.  (ultimachine) the gold i got was horrid, rarely printed at all (measured in places up to 3.6mm!) then that one was with the purple which i got maybe the bertho extruder and a mountain of failed test prints(similar issue, but still mostly extruded sometimes, then it's just stop(or they'd come out really iffy like the bertho and then break under the stress), but the last reel i got printed incredibly well (the natural pla).  and am currently experiementing with abs, so far have that printing well.  i think i'm gonna be avoiding the colored pla from ultimachine for a while just in case .-.
comments.author: maxy

comments.text: I had my diameter problems with gray PLA bought form Ultimaker, it measured 3.2mm suddenly somewhere in the middle of the roll. I used up a transparent (natural) PLA roll from http://reprapsource.comreprapsource.com, which measured 3.0mm, but very consistent, no problems at all. Maybe you should try colorfabb too, they specify 2.85 mm +/- 0.05 mm which should give you absolutely zero issues, and they claim it's flexible almost like ABS (it indeed feels much stronger, but I never tried ABS). The PLA90 from http://orbi-tech.deorbi-tech.de is also very nice to print with, more flexible, has a nice rough touch, but maybe not the best for springs.
comments.author: 4gotten

comments.text: i see, i'll try some out later, i'm trying my first reel of ABS atm, and replaced the bowden for a polyurethelane (spelling?) one with a 4.25mm ID...and am using the upgraded extruder so in theory the differences should only result in areas of minor over extrusion now. i also have a HBP installed.

description.text:
I saw this on youtube
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fD-zIUYhHps
and thought it would be a good challenge to try and figure out how it works and try and model it in SolidWorks. It took me a while to figure out but I finally sorted it out.
I haven't printed this yet as I'm waiting for a replacement print bed to arrive. I don't anticipate any issues though so it should be safe to print.
3 of these will make a 4 inch cube which is quite large, you might want to scale it down before printing.

description.text:
For fancifying flat surfaces - boiseries were originally used by woodworkers to add fancy details to their work. Suggested use: glue to a flat thing (furniture, wall, etc) and paint over for quick and easy addition of decoration to a piece.

Original art found here:
http://vintagegraphics.ohsonifty.com/vintage-vector-art-decorative-ornaments/

___.STL
3D printable file

.x3g/.gcode
Print-ready file
No Heated Bed
Left extruder: 20˚C
Infill: 100%
~Roughly 3 hours to print
Takes the entire build space of a Rep2

__.SLDPRT
Solidworks file for your editing pleasure

comments.text: hi just curious I've got a novice question, how did you convert it from a flat image to giving it its different heights, did you have to manually do it or just run it through an application? thanks
comments.author: diabolicpep

comments.text: Hi!
comments.author: diabolicpep

comments.text: thanks for the quick response, great work!! now i need to try and make a few myself sometime.
comments.author: WeeksB

comments.text: I am trying to make something VERY similar to this for a book I'm gifting to a friend, but I have no clue how to do it.
comments.author: GamerGorman20

comments.text: It took a lot of work and patience.  If you delve into the Solidworks file you'll find that it is actually poorly built and the slightest editing will most likely break it.  A more literal answer is: a lot of sweeps over three planar levels, rotations to end the sweeps, and mirroring for the horizontal and vertical symmetry.
comments.author: GamerGorman20

This is a mount for the Robo 3D which allows you to attach an iphone 4s. I had an old Iphone 4s and it now has a new purpose. This mount requires no screws, it simply clamps on. I recommend software with support enabled.

Ideally you will want to buy a fish-eye attachments of some sort. They are fairly cheap on ebay and amazon. I am using the ollo clip which requires no case, some have magnetic rings which mount to the camera.

The iphone also has a timlapse setting on the camera.

a coat of Aquanet extra super hold.

author: Krimsonek

title: Customizable GoPro Tube clamp with standard or buckle mounts

description.text:
Update, July 19, 2015, v1.0.5. Added an additional rotate parameter, allowing you to mount to a vertical tube while keeping the goPro oriented properly.

Also added pre-rendered STL files, for those that didn't want to use OpenSCAd or the customizer.

Enjoy!

This clamps to a tube/stick/pipe and has options of a standard GoPro tab mount with bolt hole, or a new quick-release buckle style. Fully configurable.

If there's a dimension that you need to configure, but can't - let me know, it would be really easy to tweak or expose other variables.

Open with Customizer, and then build it twice, once for the top and once for the bottom (with same settings otherwise). The preview mode is great for adjusting settings and seeing results, but cannot be directly built - only one part at a time.

The main options are to choose the type of mount, whether it is rotated, and then the diameter of the tube for the mount.

I've also made the clamp bolt dimensions adjustable, the defaults just fit some bolts I had lying around.

All of the other parameters are configurable but hidden, so if you're advanced, download the opens cad file and have fun!

comments.text:

Since these tabs are a standard size I would not expect that it would resize with as the width of the clamp is modified.

title: Scalar - Calibration Set of plastic parts

description.text:
Those things are mainly calibration items that you can use to calibrate your 3D Printer.

Updates:

  • 2016.01.22 : Add Cad files for Calibration objects
  • 2016.01.22: Add retraction calibration object
  • 2015.08.10: Add Scalar - RippleCalibration_v2.stl, similar model but the pattern is in both X and Y axis

-Clovert.stl: A small clover shaped part with round and flat sides.
-Scalar - Calibration_High_Frequencies.stl: small part with very high frequency shape, it will help you check that the printer is capable to print high detailed parts.
-Scalar RippeCalibration.stl and Scalar - RippleCalibration_v2.stl: A flat part meant to be print vertically. On one side you will find vertical pattern with some low and high frequency patterns. The other side has different size of round shaped holes. You will be able to see possible ripples due to vibration with this calibration part.
-Scalar - Calibration_Roundness.stl: Made to check the roundness capabilities of the printer. Different size of cylindrical shapes on top of each other shaped as a pyramid.
-Calibration_retraction.stl: is composed of a few towers spaced differently from each other. Print them empty, the goal is to test that the retraction is working great.

title: Scalar - Power supply set
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This set of parts are used on Scalar Family 3D printer's power supply (check http://www.3dmodularsystems.com)

You will find the bottom part used to mount the power supply vertically on the Z axis of the printer.

The support chassis top part is used to keep the power supply from moving too much.

Finally the more obvious part is the PowerBox_LCD_simple part. It's used to insert a standard IEC power plug with integrated fuse holder and power switch.
It will also cover the power supply terminals and prevent user from touching them.
Also it's equipped with a small hole dedicated to cheap digital voltmeter (the one with 2 wires and with the fixing hole at the top (you can find many models, both with the fixing hole at the middle or at the top of the module)

Updates:

  • Oct 4th 2016: added the missing CAD files.
  • Oct 4th 2016: Added V2 and V3 of the box (mainly the thickness of the shell has been increased, the box is more robust and easier to print.
  • Oct 9th 2015: Added assembly instruction video link to this thing description

Assembly instructions:

  • [3DMS][Scalar] Power supply assembly instructions EN+FR : https://youtu.be/8FpHVyYm9ZA

Inner Dimensions :
114x51 mm
Added model for inner dimensions 115x51

Have a great printing experience!

author: 3DModularSystems

title: DROK LM2596 Voltage Switching Regulator Case

description.text: This is a remix of thing:745463 designed specifically for the DROK LM2596 Voltage Switching Regulator available online at places like Amazon. The case includes a space for the LED voltage readout and holes designed to align with the LED display select buttons for Input / Output voltage and the voltage up / down. There are also two plastic pins which can be used to make selections.

Just a note that the voltage regulator just sits in the case. I used some double sided padded tape to keep it in place, but it isn't really necessary. You could pass short M3 bolts (or small screws) through the board and out the back slits if you need to mount it permanently.

title: Cup Holder pool floaty
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a floating cup holder! designed to be put in a pool and hold a cup! It is pretty stable and can hold a pretty good sized cup with it's 9 cm (3.5 inch) wide holder. Now it's easier than ever to reach your drink from the pool. designed to fit soda cans and many other types of cups perfectly!

canfloat12 is for printers with a print bed that is 12x12 inches (30.5x30.5 cm) or more. canfloat8 is designed for printers with a print be of 8x8 inches (20.5x20.5 cm) or more. The canfloat12 is recommended if you have a big enough print bed, as it is much more stable and floats better in the water. I would probably recommend that you print it with a 10-25% infill.

author: pucksurfer

description.text: handline

Hello,

Here is my first project using the hot wind created by a heat source.

As the heat of a light bulb in this case.

I use two cylindrical magnets Neodymium 6mm diameter x 10mm to keep levitating the propeller.
A magnet is on the support and another one on the propeller with identical poles opposed.
(You can fix the magnets with a little epoxy glue)
The strength of the hot wind is very light so this is an effective way to reduce friction.

You can then hang a sheet of paper that is attached around the propeller (With tape) with all the patterns that we imagine to create play of shadows on the walls.

I have not printed yet, so it's possible that I slightly modified the parts. (may be slightly to change the spacing between the magnets)

At first, I think using drawings made by my daughter but I'm working on several versions of thin cylinders made with PLA with different patterns.

I modeled all the parts so that they are printed on my little printer (micro delta) so they get into all other printers normally :-)
The support is large enough for a standard bulb but be careful not to put one with a strong power.

I'll post pictures when all the pieces will be printed out and I hope you will send me your creations with the drawings of your children for example, I show them to my daughter ...

Good print.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/c9S9m2Zt43U

The purpose of this object (Sans the padlock and the Ring) is to be able to lock a Ball Closure Ring (Piercing jewelry) shut using a padlock. The dimensions I modeled this on, were: a 22mm X 3.2mm(8g) BCR (Would have to be re-scaled for different sized jewlery) and a generic small padlock which I had on my desk.
I'm saving up for a 3D printer, So I wont get to see how it looks yet IRL, but I'm pretty sure the scale is good.

Also, the padlock and BCR are really just in there for scale and demonstration purposes, they would be deleted before printing.

(NOTE: It is irresponsible to try and lock your piercings. The only reason I'm interested in it is that I'm a sick puppy.)

author: cenkaetaya

description.text:
A simple toy to demonstrate Archimedes principle and Boyles law.

Archimedes principle states that a body immersed in a fluid experiences a buoyant force equal to the weight of the fluid it displaces. Using Boyle's law we then change the amount of fluid displaced to make the quarter sub rise and fall. This is achieved by simply squeezing the bottle which reduces the volume of air in the main chamber due to an increase in pressure and this in turn reduces its buoyant force (Boyle’s Law).

http://youtu.be/liPob68-oFM

Parts required:

  • The main chamber (8.2cm^3) Internal air cavity volume 11cm^3
  • The basket (1.4cm^3)
  • Displacement plugs (1 cm^3)
  • A semi ridged bottle with good lid
  • A couple of US Quarters or other weight.

Printing:
This is a 3 part print. All parts are designed to be scaled and can be printed without a raft or any support material. For the Quarter Sub to work the main chamber must be sealed and not allow air to be squeezed out. I have used the following settings:

  • ABS or PLA 100% fill at 0.2mm layers
  • ABS 80% fill at 0.2mm layers using an Acetone rinse to seal the chamber.

The Experiment and Fine Tuning:

  • Print the parts as above.
  • Add a weight: 80% fill ABS 2 US Quarters (11.3 Grams); 100% fill ABS or PLA 1 US Quarter (5.7grams).
  • Fill the bottle with water, gently drop the Quarter Sub in then close the lid.
  • Squeeze the bottle to see the Quarter Sub Drop and release to watch it rise.
  • If the Sub sinks use less weight. If it requires too much force or won't sink then you will need to add some displacement plugs. These will be required for ABS at 100%. Some trial and error may be required here.

The Math:
The buoyant force of the Quarter Sub:

Fb = pfluid Vsubmergedg

In the system pfluid and g remain a constant. To change Vsubmerged we use Boyle's law which in short states: assuming the temperature of the gas does not change when the volume is halved, the pressure is doubled; and if the volume is doubled, the pressure is halved.

V submerged(For the air) = P1V1 = P2V2 because we have a closed system V1 is constant therefore V2 = (V1P1)/P2.

So by squeezing the bottle P2 increases and the volume of air in the chamber is reduced therefore the Quarter sub will begin to sink. Releasing the pressure increases the volume of air and restores its original buoyant force.

For the record my 3 year old couldn’t care less about the math but loves to make the sub rise and fall.

Density of PLA aprox 1.25 g/cm^3
Density of ABS aprox 1.04 g/cm^3

description.text:
(10/19/2016)
I did retraction calibration for B'struder.

Extruder drive: B’struder
Kysan Nema 17 5.18:1 geared stepper motor, 2.4 V, 1.0 A

config.g of RepRapFirmware-dc42 1.12a

M92 411.230
M201 X4000 Y4000 Z4000 E3000 ; Accelerations (mm/s^2)
M203 X15000 Y15000 Z15000 E15000 ; Maximum speeds (mm/min)
M906 X800 Y800 Z800 E800 ; Set motor currents (mA)
M92 411.230

Retraction setting in Slic3r 1.2.9:
Length: 3.4 mm
Z Lift: 0.4 mm
Speed: 15 mm/s (10 mm/s and 20 mm/s give similar result.)
Retraction after layer change: on
Wipe on retraction: on

Filament: eSun PLA 1.75 mm
Layer height: 0.2 mm
Printing speed: 20 mm/s
Travel speed: 250 mm/s

190 degrees Celsius gave better result than 180 degrees Celsius. Why?!
(3/16/2016)

White one was done by RepRapPro Fisher last year.
There was huge improvement in retraction quality.
Only modification I did I glued end of Bowden tube on the push fitting of the extruder half year ago.

190 C or 180C wouldn't make much difference.

Slic3r settings (3/16/2016):
Layer height: 0.25 mm
Travel speed: 200 mm/s

Retraction
Length: 2 mm
Lift Z: 0.4 mm
Speed: 40 mm/s
Minimum travel after retraction: 2 mm
Retract on layer change: on
Wipe while retracting: on

Previous Slic3r settings (2015):
Layer height; 0.1 mm
Extrusion width: 0.28 mm
Printing speed: 30 mm/s
Travel speed: 20 mm/s
Retraction
Length: 4.5 mm
Lift Z: 0.075 mm
Speed: 150 mm/s
Extra length on restart: 0.1 mm

Source:
Fine Positive Features Performance

Sheet resistance measurement block that uses 1.25mm adhesive copper foil contacts and suitable for multi-meters with standard 2mm probes.

1. Print model in ABS or PLA, 20-50% infill.

  2. Cut out 2 x copper foil contacts 60mm x 26mm in size.

  3. Insert one of the copper foil contacts into the slots in the model with the adhesive backing facing outwards. You may first have to use a thin blade to trim off any excess plastic in the slot.

  4. Push the copper foil all the way through to the other side, so that it is in the middle of the model.

  5. Peel back the adhesive backing on both ends of the foil and trim off the backing so you can seal the ends of the foil onto the side of the model.

  6. Repeat above steps for the other foil contact.

This is a mounting kit I made to attach an 80mm fan on the side of my Prusa printer for cooling.  
The kit has three parts:  A frame rod clip, a slotted arm, and a fan frame.  It has multiple axis of tilt to adjust for wherever you place it.   You will need a couple 10mm M3 screws and nuts to assemble it, plus the appropriate screws (M3 or 4-40) for your fan.  There is a small integrated clip to secure the fan wires to the slotted frame to keep things tidy.  
The frame clip piece is designed with M8 threaded rod in mind.  You can clamp it securely to the bar using the provided holes in the side of the clip, although I have found it to be very secure without any extra help.  
The parts have a printed volume of 15.56 cubic centimeters, and require a build volume of 81x81.5x12.7mm.
